part2.question:
Describe a time when you gave advice to others. You should say:
When it was
To whom you gave the advice
What the advice was
And explain why you gave the advice.
part2.model_answer: I vividly recall a time when my cousin was Reluctant [不情愿的] to choose a university major. I gave him some Constructive [建设性的] advice about following his passion rather than just money. Since we were In the same boat [处境相同] a few years ago, I completely understood his confusion and fear. I shared a Word of wisdom [至理名言] my father told me: "Choose a job you love, and you will never work a day in your life." He was very Grateful [感激的] for my help and chose Art History. I felt it was a Sensible [明智的] thing to do because he was so lost. He was Hesitant [犹豫的] at first but listened.

part2.question:
Describe a time you received useful advice from someone. You should say:
Who gave you the advice
What the situation was
How you applied the advice
And explain how this advice helped you.
part2.model_answer: I was extremely Hesitant [犹豫的] about quitting my part-time job last year to focus on study. My best friend gave me some advice that I really Take it to heart [铭记在心]. Although I was worried about money, she told me my mental health was Indispensable [不可或缺的] and grades were more important. Her advice was Efficient [高效的] in helping me decide quickly. I am Grateful [感激的] because she helped me see the situation clearly without emotion. As a result, my grades improved significantly. It was a Sensible [明智的] decision. She was Reluctant [不情愿的] to tell me at first.

part2.question:
Describe a situation where you had to make a difficult decision. You should say:
What the decision was
Who you consulted for help
What the outcome was
And explain how you felt after making the decision.
part2.model_answer: I had to decide whether to study abroad or stay home for university. I was Reluctant [不情愿的] to leave my family because we are close. Provided that I got a scholarship, I knew it was the Sensible [明智的] choice to go for my future career. My teacher gave me a Word of wisdom [至理名言] about taking risks while I am young. In the end, I made a Constructive [建设性的] plan for my future and applied. It was hard, but I don't regret it. I was Hesitant [犹豫的] but my parents were Grateful [感激的] for my ambition. I learned to Take it to heart [铭记在心].

part3.question: Should people prepare before giving advice?
part3.model_answer: Opinion Yes, they should be prepared and Objective [客观的] before offering their thoughts or guidance to others. Reason Giving wrong advice can hurt people or make the situation much worse than before for everyone. Example Unless you know the full story, giving advice is like The blind leading the blind [问道于盲] which helps no one.

part3.question: Is it good to ask for advice from strangers online?
part3.model_answer: Opinion It is usually not a good idea due to significant Privacy [隐私] risks involved in sharing data. Reason Strangers don't care about your specific Dilemma [进退两难的困境] or personal feelings like your friends do. Example Although you might get a quick answer, you might Learn the hard way [吃一堑长一智] that their advice is bad or harmful.

part3.question: What are the personalities of people whose job is to give advice to others?
part3.model_answer: Opinion They usually have a lot of Wisdom [智慧] and patience when dealing with other people's problems. Reason Jobs like Counseling [咨询] require deep empathy to understand others' pain and complex life problems. Example Since they deal with sensitive issues, they must be calm and kind at all times to be effective.

part3.question: What are the problems if you ask too many people for advice?
part3.model_answer: Opinion You might become confused and unable to make a clear decision for yourself due to the noise. Reason When you hear too many conflicting opinions, you might just Sit on the fence [保持中立/观望] and do nothing. Example Excessive input hinders clear Intervention [干预] in your own problems and causes unnecessary mental stress.

part3.question: Is the advice given by older generations still relevant to the problems young people face today?
part3.model_answer: Opinion Sometimes their Wisdom [智慧] is timeless, but not always relevant to modern problems we face today. Reason The modern world has changed, especially regarding technology and Privacy [隐私] norms in society and workplaces. Example While their life values are good, their career advice might be outdated for the digital age we live in.

part3.question: To what extent does professional counseling differ from advice given by friends or family?
part3.model_answer: Opinion Counseling [咨询] is professional and Objective [客观的], unlike friendly advice which is often biased and emotional. Reason Friends might be biased because of their personal relationship with you and your shared history together, leading to Subjective [主观的] advice. Example Whereas a friend gives emotional support, a counselor provides structured Intervention [干预] strategies for solutions.
